children.subject: I did not take CS 70, but I have taken Math 55 and Stats 134, do you think it will be easier for me on EE 126?

I'm assuming you've taken CS 70, you can compare the workload of 126 to the probability potion of 70, although a bit harder. Requires a lot more intuition and better understanding of the concepts. First few weeks especially are the hardest but the homework gets easier as you go on.
110 is less work than 126 and 189. 126 is a bit more than 170 (also depends on your own background, but generally, I'd say this is true). 189 is also more than 170.
I'm taking CS 188 right now, and I think for me data 100 was a bit less work but relatively similar.

I've taken 126, 127, and 189. I've also taken 170 and all the lower divs. I'd say that classes like 61X are ~5-8 hours of homework a week (obviously this grows and shrinks based off of project deadlines). CS 170 took me about ~6-8 hours a week doing homework as well. In contrast, in my experience, 126 and 127 had about 10-12 hours of homework a week. When I took these classes you did not need to complete all the homework but not doing so put you at a direct disadvantage when it came to exams, so I tried to. CS 189 has been absolutely brutal at easily 20+ hours spent on homework each week. In general, these more math-y CS classes seem to give a lot more work than both pure CS and pure Math classes. My friends who have taken Data 100, Stat 134, and Math 110 put them at about the same level as CS 170.

I have taken all 61s, 16s, 188, 126 170 and 100. Using upper divs as an example, I thought 170 was much more work for me than 126, and I dont consider myself good at probability much at all. 126 has a pretty rough start, but it seems that the work tapers off a bit after the first midterm, although it can still be easily 10 or more hours on homework a week. 188 is a bit more work than 100 I would say, but its not bad at all, at least personally. 
I am taking 189 next semester, and have done a lot of comparison between the fall and spring iterations. I think its an important distinction to make, because if you look at the homeworks for fa20 and sp20, you can see a drastic difference in average lengths of the homeworks. I also think that shewchucks spring iteration gives you two weeks to do homeworks that have similar or lower length than falls, which can have upwards of 10+ questions with coding portions that are given to do in a week (RIP).Take this analysis with a grain of salt (I havent taken 189 yet), and I would also advise you to look at the sp20 and fa20 189 websites and briefly browse through the homeworks to see which version you would rather take.

history.content:
I am wondering if anyone can compare the workload of upper-division courses in ML/optimization direction.

Such as: EECS 126, EECS 127, CS189, EECS 227B, EECS 227C, Data100 (call it List A)

I have taken CS170, CS188, all CS61X, Math 104, Math 110, Stats 134, and Stats 135, (Call it List B) 

Could you compare any the difficulty and workload of any of the courses in List A to any of the courses in List B?
history.subject: Workload of upper div courses
